How to Install Windows 10 (with Pictures) - wikiHow 
 Home Random Browse Articles Notifications Add to This Page Add Tip Easy Ways to Help Approve Questions Review Tech Feedback Fix Spelling More Things to Try...   
 Log in / Sign up   
 Desktop Site   
 Community Tested How to Install Windows 10   
 This wikiHow teaches you how to install Windows 10 on your PC. To do this, you'll need to hold down a key while Windows is starting up, which will launch a menu that lets you start the computer from either a USB drive or a CD/DVD with the Windows 10 installer on it. 
 Steps Edit 
 Part One of Two: Booting to the Windows 10 Installer Edit 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/f\/f1\/Burn-a-DVD-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\/v4-460px-Burn-a-DVD-Step-10-Version-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/f\/f1\/Burn-a-DVD-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\/v4-760px-Burn-a-DVD-Step-10-Version-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 1 
 Make sure your Windows 10 installation media is connected. 
In order for you to install Windows 10, your Windows 10 installation file must be loaded onto a disc or flash drive, and the disc or flash drive must be inserted into your computer.
 If you haven't yet downloaded the Windows 10 installation tool, follow the instructions from this Microsoft support page:  https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/software-download/windows10 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/76\/Install-Windows-10-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\/v4-460px-Install-Windows-10-Step-2-Version-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/76\/Install-Windows-10-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\/v4-760px-Install-Windows-10-Step-2-Version-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 2 
 Open the Start menu.  Either click the Windows icon in the bottom-left corner of the screen, or press the  ⊞  Win  key.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/25\/Install-Windows-10-Step-3-Version-2.jpg\/v4-460px-Install-Windows-10-Step-3-Version-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/25\/Install-Windows-10-Step-3-Version-2.jpg\/v4-760px-Install-Windows-10-Step-3-Version-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 3 
 Click the power icon.  This is the circle with a line through its top that's in the bottom-left corner of the Start window.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/c6\/Install-Windows-10-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\/v4-460px-Install-Windows-10-Step-4-Version-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/c6\/Install-Windows-10-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\/v4-760px-Install-Windows-10-Step-4-Version-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 4 
 Click  Restart .  It's in the pop-up menu above the power icon. Doing so will restart your computer.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/a\/af\/Install-Windows-10-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\/v4-460px-Install-Windows-10-Step-5-Version-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/a\/af\/Install-Windows-10-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\/v4-760px-Install-Windows-10-Step-5-Version-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 5 
 Press and hold  Del  or  F2  to enter setup.  This key may also be a different key—most computers will display a message on startup that says "Press [key] to enter setup" or something similar, so look for this message when your computer restarts to confirm the key you should press to  access the BIOS .
 Consult your computer's manual or online support page to confirm your computer's BIOS key. 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/95\/Install-Windows-10-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\/v4-460px-Install-Windows-10-Step-6-Version-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/95\/Install-Windows-10-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\/v4-760px-Install-Windows-10-Step-6-Version-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 6 
 Navigate to the  Boot  tab.  You'll use the arrow keys to select it.
 The  Boot  tab may instead say  Boot Options , depending on your computer's manufacturer. 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/5\/5c\/Install-Windows-10-Step-7.jpg\/v4-460px-Install-Windows-10-Step-7.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/5\/5c\/Install-Windows-10-Step-7.jpg\/v4-760px-Install-Windows-10-Step-7.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 7 
 Select a device from which to boot.  You have a couple of options here:
 For a  USB flash drive , select the  Removable Devices  option. 
 For a  disc installation , select the  CD-ROM Drive  option. 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/5\/54\/Install-Windows-10-Step-8.jpg\/v4-460px-Install-Windows-10-Step-8.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/5\/54\/Install-Windows-10-Step-8.jpg\/v4-760px-Install-Windows-10-Step-8.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 8 
 Press the  +  key until your boot option is first.  Once either  Removable Devices  or  CD-ROM Drive  is at the top of the list, your computer will select your choice as its default boot option.
 On some computers, you'll instead press one of the function keys (e.g.,  F5 ) to navigate an option up to the top of the menu. The key will be listed on the right side of the screen. 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/26\/Install-Windows-10-Step-9.jpg\/v4-460px-Install-Windows-10-Step-9.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/26\/Install-Windows-10-Step-9.jpg\/v4-760px-Install-Windows-10-Step-9.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 9 
 Save your settings.  You should see a key prompt (e.g.,  F10 ) at the bottom of the screen that correlates to "Save and Exit"; pressing it should save your settings and restart your computer.
 You may have to press  ↵  Enter  to confirm the changes. 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/f\/f4\/Install-Windows-10-Step-10.jpg\/v4-460px-Install-Windows-10-Step-10.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/f\/f4\/Install-Windows-10-Step-10.jpg\/v4-760px-Install-Windows-10-Step-10.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 10 
 Wait for your computer to restart.  Once your computer finishes restarting, you'll see a window here with your geographical data. You're now ready to begin setting up your Windows 10 installation.
 Advertisement 
 Part Two of Two: Installing Edit 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/49\/Install-Windows-10-Step-11.jpg\/v4-460px-Install-Windows-10-Step-11.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/49\/Install-Windows-10-Step-11.jpg\/v4-760px-Install-Windows-10-Step-11.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 1 
 Click  Next  when prompted.  You can also change the options on this page (e.g., the setup language) before continuing if need be.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/ca\/Install-Windows-10-Step-12.jpg\/v4-460px-Install-Windows-10-Step-12.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/ca\/Install-Windows-10-Step-12.jpg\/v4-760px-Install-Windows-10-Step-12.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 2 
 Click  Install Now .  It's in the middle of the window.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/14\/Install-Windows-10-Step-13.jpg\/v4-460px-Install-Windows-10-Step-13.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/14\/Install-Windows-10-Step-13.jpg\/v4-760px-Install-Windows-10-Step-13.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 3 
 Enter your Windows 10 key, then click  Next .  If you don't have a Windows 10 key, instead click  Skip  in the bottom-right corner of the screen.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/f\/f7\/Install-Windows-10-Step-14.jpg\/v4-460px-Install-Windows-10-Step-14.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/f\/f7\/Install-Windows-10-Step-14.jpg\/v4-760px-Install-Windows-10-Step-14.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 4 
 Click the "Accept" box and click  Next .  This will indicate that you accept the terms of use.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/44\/Install-Windows-10-Step-15.jpg\/v4-460px-Install-Windows-10-Step-15.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/44\/Install-Windows-10-Step-15.jpg\/v4-760px-Install-Windows-10-Step-15.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 5 
 Click  Upgrade .  It's at the top of the "Which type of installation do you want?" window. This option installs Windows 10 while preserving your files, apps, and settings.
 You can click  Custom  instead to clean install Windows 10 on your computer. Doing so will prompt you to select a partition to format before continuing. 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/b8\/Install-Windows-10-Step-16.jpg\/v4-460px-Install-Windows-10-Step-16.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/b8\/Install-Windows-10-Step-16.jpg\/v4-760px-Install-Windows-10-Step-16.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 6 
 Wait for Windows 10 to install.  This process may take anywhere from half an hour to several hours, depending on your computer's previous operating system and processing speed.
 If prompted to press a key in order to boot from a CD,  do not press a key . 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/48\/Install-Windows-10-Step-17.jpg\/v4-460px-Install-Windows-10-Step-17.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/48\/Install-Windows-10-Step-17.jpg\/v4-760px-Install-Windows-10-Step-17.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 7 
 Follow the on-screen setup instructions.  Once Windows 10 has been installed on your computer, you'll be able to customize its settings (e.g., your region, your preferred language, location settings, etc.). Once you finish this process, you will be taken to your computer's desktop.
 You can also click  Express Settings  to set up Windows 10 with the recommended settings. 
 Advertisement 
 Community Q&A 
 Search 
 Add New Question 
 What button do I press for boot options? 
								Answered by  
								wikiHow Contributor							 
 This is commonly F12, but can vary, depending on manufacturer.  Your system will tell you which key to press upon first turning on the machine.   
 Thanks!

 Tips Edit 
 If you don't enter a Windows 10 activation key when prompted to do so, you'll receive a free trial of Windows 10. After the trial ends, you'll be prompted to purchase and enter an activation key. 
 0 
 Helpful? 
   0 
 Add 
 Warnings Edit 
 Some computers won't be able to run Windows 10 well. If your computer is an older model that runs Windows 7 at an average pace, you shouldn't upgrade to Windows 10. 
 1 
 Helpful? 
   0 
 Make sure you have enough space on the computer on which you wish to install Windows 10.
